title: Harry Foran
text:
Martin Henry "Harry" Foran (c. 1850 – 25 April 1908) was an Australian schoolteacher and journalist.
Foran was born near <a href="Kilkee">Kilkee</a> in <a href="County%20Clare">County Clare</a> to James Forhen, head of a fishing family. After considering the priesthood Foran became a student teacher in 1871, but legal trouble associated with his involvement in tenant reform and the campaign for <a href="Home%20Rule">Home Rule</a> led him to migrate to <a href="Victoria%20%28Australia%29">Victoria</a> in 1876. He returned to teaching, and again became known as a troublemaker; his licence was withheld until 1885 in an attempt to be rid of him. He was suspended on charges of disciplinary and sexual misconduct in 1888; although he was cleared, the case was reopened in April 1889 and he was dismissed, losing a subsequent appeal to the <a href="Supreme%20Court%20of%20Victoria">Supreme Court</a>. The case attracted significant media attention and Foran became something of a celebrity.
Relocating to <a href="Sydney">Sydney</a> in 1893, Foran worked as a journalist and a regular speaker in the <a href="The%20Domain%2C%20Sydney">Domain</a>. Appealing mainly to the <a href="Catholic">Catholic</a> working class, he became associated with the radical wing of the <a href="Protectionist%20Party">Protectionist Party</a>, opposing the <a href="Australian%20Labor%20Party">Labour Leagues</a> on the grounds of "atheistic socialism, opportunism and Protestant bigotry". He edited "Sydney Irish World" from 1894 to 1895 and ran for the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Parliament">New South Wales Parliament</a> in 1894, 1895, 1898 and 1901 as an <a href="independent%20%28politician%29">independent</a>, without success; he came second to Premier <a href="George%20Reid%20%28Australian%20politician%29">George Reid</a> running for the <a href="1901%20Australian%20federal%20election">first federal election</a> in <a href="Division%20of%20East%20Sydney">East Sydney</a>. During this time he earned the nicknames the "Domain <a href="Demosthenes">Demosthenes</a>" and "the Mayor of <a href="Hyde%20Park%2C%20Sydney">Hyde Park</a>".
In 1902, he returned to <a href="Melbourne">Melbourne</a> and continued his activities on Yarra Bank, running for <a href="Division%20of%20Melbourne%20Ports">Melbourne Ports</a> in 1903. Despite his early opposition he joined the <a href="Australian%20Labor%20Party">Labor Party</a> in 1904; he contributed occasionally to the Catholic weekly the "Tribune" and was clearly associated with the Labor Party's Catholic wing. His health, however, began to fail and he died almost penniless at <a href="St%20Vincent%27s%20Hospital%2C%20Melbourne">St Vincent's Hospital</a> in <a href="Fitzroy%2C%20Victoria">Fitzroy</a> of <a href="jaundice">jaundice</a> and <a href="hydatids">hydatids</a>. He was remembered variously as a "political failure", a "knight of the Southern Cross" and "probably the most fluent public speaker in Australia".
